conclusion: On a v-t graph the acceleration of an object equals the slope (dv/dt).
At t₁ the two curves intersect, so v_A = v_B.
Curve A has a negative slope, therefore a_A < 0.
Curve B is a straight rising line.
Curve B has a positive constant slope, therefore a_B > 0.

At the instant t₁ the velocity–time curve for object A is sloping downward (its acceleration is negative), whereas the velocity-time curve for object B is sloping upward with a constant positive slope.
Because the slopes of the two curves are different, their accelerations at t₁ are different in both magnitude and sign.
